notes:
1. Concept

A Linear Variable Differential Transformer (LVDT) is a common type of electromechanical transducer that can convert the rectilinear motion of an object to which it is coupled into a corresponding electrical signal.

2. Principle of Operation

An LVDT consists of a primary coil and two secondary coils, symmetrically wound on a hollow tube. A movable ferromagnetic core is placed inside this tube. An AC excitation voltage is applied to the primary coil.

  • When the core is at the center (null position), the magnetic flux from the primary coil links equally with both secondary coils. The voltages induced in the secondaries ($V_{S1}$ and $V_{S2}$) are equal but 180Â° out of phase. The differential output voltage ($V_{out} = V_{S1} - V_{S2}$) is zero.
  • When the core is displaced from the center, more flux links with one secondary coil than the other. This creates a non-zero differential output voltage.
  • The magnitude of the output voltage is proportional to the magnitude of the displacement. The phase of the output voltage indicates the direction of the displacement.

3. Advantages

LVDTs are widely used due to their high accuracy, high resolution, frictionless operation (no physical contact between core and coils), and robustness.

solvedExamples.question: What physical quantity does an LVDT primarily measure?
solvedExamples.explanation: LVDT stands for Linear Variable Differential Transformer. Its primary function is to measure linear displacement (position).

solvedExamples.question: In an LVDT, what is the output voltage when the core is at its central (null) position?
solvedExamples.explanation: At the null position, the magnetic coupling to both secondary coils is equal and opposite. This results in a differential output voltage of zero.
